title: 107_hr1526
content: The "Agriculture Competition Enhancement Act of 2001" limits mergers in the agricultural industry to prevent negative effects on prices paid to producers of livestock, poultry, or basic agricultural commodities. It prohibits acquiring voting securities or assets if the total amount exceeds $1,000,000,000 and would reduce competition. The "Agriculture Competition Enhancement Act of 2001" restricts mergers in the agricultural industry to safeguard prices for producers of livestock, poultry, and basic agricultural commodities. It mandates filing notifications with the Secretary for wholesale purchases and allows for public comments on proposed mergers. The Secretary reviews acquisitions within 30 days to assess their potential impact on producer prices. The "Agriculture Competition Enhancement Act of 2001" requires the Secretary to review proposed acquisitions in the agricultural industry to assess their impact on producer prices. The Secretary must prepare a report with detailed findings and an economic analysis on whether the acquisition may reduce competition or create a monopoly. The report must be transmitted to the Office of Special Counsel for Agriculture and published in the Federal Register. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT PROVISIONS: Clayton Act sections apply to section 2 violations. SEC. 5. SPECIAL COUNSEL FOR AGRICULTURE: Office established for agricultural antitrust issues. SEC. 6. GAO STUDY. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the Grain Inspection, Packers and Stockyard Administration's need for additional resources to monitor the meat packing industry and disparities in administrative authority. A report will be submitted to Congress within 1 year. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms used in the Act, such as "antitrust laws," "basic agricultural commodity," "livestock," "person," "poultry," and "Secretary."
